text: Waves lap against a sand beach. A 12 year old BOY, MICHAE stands facing the still water, his back to us.
There are many stories about Michael Sullivan. Some say he was a decent man. Some say there was no good in him at all. But I once spent six weeks on the road with him in the winter of 1931.
This is our story.

A dark spec emerges over the crest of a hill from endless white snow: MICHAEL SULLIVAN, 12, biking towards us with satchel of newspapers over his shoulder. His face is wrapped in a long woolen scarf. He speeds along, dwarfed by a vast stretch of CLOSED FACTORIES. Smoke billows from a pair of smoke stacks. WORKERS pour o the gated entrance.
Michael stands in the tide of workers, holding up his pap

Thank you, sir. Much obliged to you. Man dies in factory accident! Get your paper here! Various workers dig in pockets for change. MICHAEL (CONT’D) Hot off the press, only five cents! Michael rides his bike through a throng of walking worker
Michael rides past another huge factory.
Michael cycles down main street. Cars drive in both directions. He cycles down the center of the road. The ca narrowly miss him on either side. He cycles past some BOARDED UP SHOPS, stopping outside:

Michael parks his bike. Enters. He drops his NEWSPAPER BA on the counter. The OWNER counts the papers as Michael unwraps his scarf. Now we see his FACE for the first time. Innocent. Inquisitive. Michael pays for the papers he’s sold. As for the owner rings up the transaction, Michael takes a pouch of BUGLER TOBACCO from the counter. While Michael receives his commission change with one hand, the other hand slips the tobacco into the waistband of his trousers.
Thanks, Mister Miller Michael walks out onto the street.
Michael is cycling along, one hand to steer the bike, the other to puff on his lit PIPE. EXT. ST. PETER’S CHURCH - DAY Michael passes by a CATHOLIC CHURCH.

Michael coasts onto a long, tree-lined driveway leading u a large HOUSE. To the side is a detached GARAGE. Woods beyond. Michael senses danger... Suddenly, a FIGURE lunges out fr behind a tree and throws a snowball. It is his brother, PETER, 10. Michael is hit and FALLS off his bike spectacularly, the pipe flying from his mouth. (CONTINUED )

He picks up a snowball and fires one back at PETER who fa backwards, stunned, as if shot in the forehead. Peter rolls on the ground until he is still. MICHAEL and PETER lie a few yards apart. ‘Dead’. Their breath smoking in the air.
CLOSE: Reflection in glass window of the boys in the snow A woman’s face looks out and smiles.
From inside the house their mother, ANNIE SULLIVAN, 40's, watches Michael and Peter lying in the snow. Sound of a distant car approaching.

Michael and Peter leap to their feet dusting off the snow their clothes. A CAR appears in the driveway. They stand, almost to attention, as the car approaches. Michael buries his pipe in the snow with his foot. The car drives past them. PETER CHASES the car to the GAR Michael watches.

Michael and Peter are doing their HOMEWORK at the table. Annie is cooking. Michael looks down to his work: Math. A BLANK page. He glances at Peter who writes fluently in hi school book. Annie senses her eldest son struggling with homework. It’s not an unusual occurrence. She moves over him, bends down, whispering in his ear conspiratorially:
I‘1l help you with it later.... Michael smiles. She kisses his cheek.
You go fetch your father.

Michael comes up the stairs onto the landing. At the end the CORRIDOR is the half-open door to his parents’ bedroo through which he glimpses his father, SULLIVAN. We don’t see his face. ON MICHAEL: watching in silence, cautious yet fascinated the mysteries of a father’s ritual: CLOSE: Sullivan removes his tie and gracefully lays it on bed... Next to it, he lays some keys and rosary beads... removes a holstered Colt 45 and places it next to them.
Pa? Sullivan senses his son. He removes his jacket and places over the gun.
Mm-hm.
Dinner’s ready.
Thank you. Michael walks back down the corridor.
A formal scene: family at table. Boys silent and scrubbed
(praying) Bless us oh Lord for these thy gifts which we are about to receive through the bounty of Jesus Christ our Lord. Amen.
Amen. They make the sign of the cross and begin to eat.
Sullivan sits in the driver's seat of the CAR seen before Engine is running. Michael gets in the back. (CONTINUED )
Both Sullivan and Michael are formally dressed. Sullivan looks at his son via the rear view MIRROR.
Michael.
Sir?
It’s a wake. So I don’t wanna see those dice.

No, sir. Sullivan observes him in the mirror, unsure whether he’s lying. Michael looks out the window. EXT. ROONEY’S ESTATE - DAY The CAR pulls into the circular drive of a sprawling VICTORIAN ESTATE. Sullivan and his family get out. Variou PEOPLE, some of them poor, but all of them wearing their clothes, head into the MANSION. INT. ROONEY’S MANSION - HALL - DAY Sullivan opens the door, letting them into a dark, lavish hall. MOURNERS, laughing and chattering. Old women, worki men, scruffy children; the people contrasting with the or interior. Sullivan removes his hat and steers his family through the throng into - INT. ROONEY’S MANSION - ANTE ROOM - DAY A quiet room. Annie, Sullivan and the boys enter. Sullivan and Michael O.S. to the coffin to pray their respects... As Annie follows, Peter hangs back, not wanting to go.
(whispering) I don’t want to go.
It’s all right, honey. Come on.
No. I’m scared. (CONTINUED )
Annie understands and relents, staying back. Sullivan and Michael approach. In front of a fire, an OPE COFFIN rests on a bed of ICE. Buckets catch the drips. Sullivan notices Michael’s curiosity.

Ice helps preserve the body. Sullivan and Michael kneel and pray. After a few seconds Michael peeks over the edge at the DEAD MAN; the skin, wa and pale. Pennies on his eyes. Fascinating. Michael glances at Sullivan. His eyes are closed in prayer. Sullivan makes the sign of the cross. Michael follows his lead. Sullivan rises, with Michael and turns to find ROONEY lea against the door, smiling. He is a man of 70’s, handome.
Who’s got a hug for a lonely old man? Michael and Peter rush to him, delighted. He scoops them in turn.
Now which is which? Don’t help me! (indicating to Michael) Peter. (indicating to Peter) And... Michael. The boys groan at his usual ‘mistake on purpose’. Sulliva smiles.
Annie. Mike. Good to see you.
(whispering to Michael) Did you bring the necessary? Michael nods, surreptitiously.
(excited whisper) Yes. (CONTINUED )

(to Sullivan) If you'll excuse me, I have some urgent business with these young gentleman. He leads the boys away, one on each arm. Sullivan watches them depart, quietly amused. INT. ROONEY’S MANSION - BASEMENT - EVENING CLOSE: Two DICE roll up against a white-tiled wall. Michael and Peter leap excitedly into the air.
Yeah!
(overlapping) Winner! Winner! ROONEY sits on a crate. Mock devastated. Mops his brow wi his handkerchief.
Call the cops. I know hustlers when I see ‘em.
No hustle ol’ timer!
Pay the man! Paternally, Rooney pulls Michael in, slides his arm aroun him.

Upstairs. Jacket pocket in my study. Before I change my mind INT. ROONEY’S MANSION - STAIRS - NIGHT Michael runs up the stairs. INT. ROONEY’S MANSION - CORRIDOR - NIGHT Michael looks for Rooney’s STUDY. He finds it at the end of the corridor. He pushes the doo open.  INT. ROONEY’S STUDY - NIGHT Inside, the curtains are drawn. CONNOR ROONEY, late 30's, handsome, lies on a couch, smok A glass of WHISKY beside him. As Michael enters, Connor is looking straight at him.
Hello.
Hello...
(not unfriendly) Remind me, which little Sullivan are you?
Michael, Sir.
Sir? You don’t have to call me sir. I’m not your Pa.
No, Mr. Rooney
Call me Connor. No, call me Uncle Connor. CONNOR turns away from him. MICHAEL looks at Rooney’s JAC on the back of the desk chair. Considers going to it, but too scared.
What do you want?
Mister Rooney sent me to get his jacket.
Why don’t you come back later, huh? I’m busy.
Yes... Sir. (CONTINUED )

Michael leaves, closing the door behind him. INT. ROONEY’S MANSION - GRAND PARLOR - NIGHT (LATER) CLOSE: A glass A spoon taps it. The room goes quiet. Rooney takes the stage. Takes his ha written speech out.

Hello! Hello! I want to welcome all of you to my home. It’s good to have so many friends in this house again. Since Mary died, it’s - well - it’s just been me and my boy, rattling around in these rooms... He unfolds his written speech, decides against it.

I had this speech prepared, but it would be dishonest of me to say that I knew Danny well. But lose one of us, it hurts us all. (murmurs of approval) I’1l1 tell you what I do remember though. And Finn will remember this too. And that’s... Danny on the high school football team. A championship game: down six points, ten seconds left to play, four yards to go. Danny tackles his own quarterback. (laughter) Mistakes. You know, we all make’em God knows. Rooney looks to FINN MCGOVERN, who doesn’t respond.
Let’s drink to Danny’s honor. Let’s wake him to God. All around the room the whiskey bottles come out. Rooney holds up his whiskey bottle.
And hope he gets to heaven at least an hour before the Devil finds out he’s dead. The quote captures Michael’s attention as the room drinks cries “Amen”. (CONTINUED )
ROONEY (CONT’D) To Danny!
(in unison) To Danny!
And now, our good friend, Finn McGovern, will say a few words. Words, I'll wager, that have a little more poetry than mine. Applause. McGOVERN takes the stage, Rooney hugs him.

Thank you, John. My brother Danny wasn’t wise, nor was he gentle. And with a skinfull of liquor in him... he was a pain in the ass. Gentle laughter from the crowd. MCGOVERN (CONT’D) Bute he was loyal. And brave. And he never told a lie. CLOSE: Sullivan watching McGovern closely. MCGOVERN (CONT’D) He’d’ve enjoyed this party. Me and the family, we want to say thank you to our generous host. Where would this town be without Mr. John Rooney. God love you. Big murdered approval. Rooney bows his head, humbly. MCGOVERN (CONT’D) (looking at Rooney) I’ve worked for you many years now John, nearly half my life... and we've never had a disagreement... but... CLOSE: Rooney watching. Steely. CLOSE: Sullivan, ready to take action. (CONTINUED )

MCGOVERN (CONT’D) (emotional) I’ve come to realize that you rule this town as God rules the earth... you give and take away. Swiftly, a seemingly friendly Sullivan moves up onto the makeshift stage and firmly, but gently grabs hold of Finn arm and leads him to the door. Rooney glances to the band to strike up some music. CLOSE: Michael watching. Two of Finn’s friends follow them out. CLOSE: Connor watches, then follows them out as well. EXT. ROONEY’S MANSION - NIGHT McGovern’s men walk ahead - one getting behind the wheel, opening the car door - as we remain on McGovern leaning o Sullivan who helps him walk to the car. Connor catches up to the other side of McGovern to help, McGovern swipes him away, drunk.
I’m going to bury my brother, then I’m going to deal with you. Sullivan brushes off the drunken rave.

Sure, Finn, sure. You’1ll take care of all of us once you get a good night’s sleep. Sullivan and McGovern continue, exiting off camera as we on Connor, for who this was not a drunken remark - but a direct threat. McGOVERN is helped into a TRUCK by Sullivan and McGovern’ two friends. The TRUCK pulls away. Sullivan returns to Connor’s side as the truck disappears down the driveway and Rooney approaches them.
Is he all right? (CONTINUED )
(casually) Yeah, he’s fine. Just too much to drink. I’11 talk to him.
Take Mike with you.
No, Pa - I'll be fine.

Take Mike with you... And just talk. Nothing more. Rooney walks back to the house MICHAEL is watching the three of them from the front door Sullivan sees Michael watching - wondering what he heard understood. Their eyes meet. INT. ROONEY’S MANSION - GRAND PARLOR - NIGHT It is later. The musicians are playing a REEL. The majority of the crowd are drunk and dancing. Amongst the crowd, we see the following: A YOUNG GIRL invites MICHAEL to dance. He stands up, but shakes his head, declining. ROONEY , shuffling charmingly across the room in time to music. A glass of whisky in each hand. ANNIE is dancing with SEAN, (one of Rooney’s men). She wh around, hair flying. SULLIVAN sits to the side, watching her. Connor is dancing with a young girl. He is very good - slick, smooth. On-lookers cheer him on. The music finishes. Connor ends with a deftly executed di Everyone applauds. The sound of a piano. The opening cords of an IRISH AIR. “Aaahs” from the Crowd.
(CONTINUED )

Rooney sits at the piano, playing. The room slowly goes quiet. He catches Sullivan’s eye amongst the crowd, gestu him over with his head. Sullivan joins him on the piano stool. Begins to play alo with him, hesitant at first, then gradually getting into flow. A memory of childhood. CLOSE: Connor watches his father and Sullivan through the crowd. He is smiling, though his eyes aren’t. CLOSE: Annie smiles slightly. CLOSE: Rooney and Sullivan’s hands move in concert, two h men seamlessly producing a delicate, melancholy tune. The crowd applauds. Sullivan and Rooney nod at each other an unspoken bond. Connor watches, jealous. Still grinning. He feels a presence, and looks down to see PETER.
Why are you always smiling? Connor stare at him.

‘Cause it’s all so fuckin’ hysterical. INT. SULLIVAN HOUSE - BOYS’ BEDROOM - NIGHT Michael sits in bed and uses a FLASHLIGHT to illuminate h reading. He quietly turns the page of his LONE RANGER COMIC BOOK. (N.B. These books have text on the left hand page, and a single, captioned cartoon on the right hand page] We see the page Michael reads: Plate 1: “Moonlight streamed into the room.” Suddenly, from his bed across the room, Peter whispers
Michael?
What? (CONTINUED )
I had a nightmare. It was about Mr. Rooney’s house.
It’s just a house. A big house. Go back to sleep.
Is Mr. Rooney rich like the Babe?
Richer.
(a beat) Are we rich?
No stupid. A long silence. Michael turns a page. Plate 2: “A man climbed in at the window.”
What’s Papa’s job?
He works for Mr. Rooney.
Why?
Well, Papa didn’t have a father. So, Mr. Rooney looked after him.
I know that. But what’s his job? Michael goes very still. He doesn’t know, but can’t admit it. He tries to escape back in the LONE RANGER.
(staring at the page) He goes on missions for Mr. Rooney... they’re very dangerous, that’s why he brings his gun... (CONTINUED )
Michael turns a page in the comic book. Plate 3: “He had the Sheriff covered.”
Sometimes even the President sends him on missions...because Papa was a war hero and all. Peter considers. Sober. Pronounces:
You're just making that up.
I am not! Pause. Peter sighs. Turns over in bed.
It’s all so fuckin’ hysterical. CLOSE ON MICHAEL: Genuinely shocked.
Sullivan family at breakfast. Sullivan is finishing his coffee, and putting on his jacket.
Peter, I can’t come to your concert tonight. I’m working. Michael and Peter look up.
(eyes flicking to Michael: curious) Working at what?
(swiftly) Putting food on your plate, young man. Michael continues eating, feigning disinterest.
All right, boys. Come on. Clear the plates. Peter picks up his plates and carries them toward the sin then steps over to Sullivan, who hugs him. (CONTINUED )
You're a good lad. Michael notes the gesture.
Michael sits at his DESK at the back of the classroom, ga out the window. His teacher drones on in the background. Michael’s mind is elsewhere.
Michael arrives home. He parks his bike. He looks over toward the garage. He thinks. He goes into the house.
It’s later. Rain had begun to fall. The door of the house opens. Sullivan walks out of the house, toward the garage
Sullivan's SHADOW appears in the doorway of the garage. H enters. He walks past the CAR. He unlocks a cupboard. He takes a BLACK CASE from the cupboard and gets into the car.

The car rolls out of the garage, into the rain. INT/EXT. SULLIVAN’S CAR - NIGHT The car pulls in outside the HOTEL FLORENCE. Sullivan loo out the window. CONNOR runs out the hotel and gets in the car, he sits in passenger seat. The car pulls away.  17.
Outskirts of town. Heading for the industrial area. Still raining.
You want a shot? Connor offers a flask. Sullivan shakes “No”. Connor shrug and drinks. Sullivan can tell he’s already high. Then, Connor glances to the back of the car, sees SOMETHI The BLACK CASE.
We're just talking to him. Right?
Sure. Connor lights a cigarette, crumples the empty pack, and tosses it over his shoulder.
The BLACK CASE on the back seat. Suddenly, the lid of the seat lifts, and we realize MICHAEL IS INSIDE. He lifts the seat a couple of inches and peeks out at Sullivan and Connor in the front seat.

A narrow alley among the group of brick buildings. Rain hammers the car as it rolls out of the shadows, ligh out. INT. SULLIVAN’S CAR - NIGHT MICHAEL'S POV: as he peeks out through his one inch GAP. SOUND OF: Rain crumbing on the car roof. Michael carefully lowers the seat. SULLIVAN'’s arm reaches over to pick up the black case.

INT. SULLIVAN’S CAR - UNDER SEAT - NIGHT Darkness. SOUND OF: the case being opened on the back seat. Mechani sounds. Metal locking together. Canister snapping onto gu Car door shuts. Michael, just visible, thinking. SOUND OF: The rain on the car roof. Slowly, Michael pulls himself out from the seat and looks the windshield: MICHAEL’S POV: Dark alley. Glass blurred by rain. Then... standing under a lamp over the back entrance to a WAREHOU he sees his father and Connor. Connor is knocking on the DOOR. Sullivan is holding a lon black OBJECT. Michael climbs into the front seat to see them better. Breaths too hard on the window and it fogs. Wipes it away Connor and Sullivan have gone. INT. SULLIVAN’S CAR (MINUTES LATER) Michael sits in the driver's seat. Keeping down, but watching the warehouse door. He makes a decision.

Michael moves through the shadows. He goes to the door. Hear VOICES inside, faint. He needs see. Spots something further down the alley - A SMALL DOOR A few planks at the bottom rotted away. Dim light spills into the alley. Michael moves to the door. Peers in through THE gap at th bottom. MICHAEL’S POV: in the center of a huge WAREHOUSE, FINN McGOVERN sits in a chair. (CONTINUED )
Connor stands. He’s in the middle of talking to McGOVERN. No sign of Sullivan.

.-.-don’t get me wrong, Finn. I feel for you. I do. But you can’t leta thing like that give you cause to go mouthing off. You and my dad go back many years. He’s a just man. (smiles sympathetically) So what do you say? McGovern glances beyond Connor’s shoulder at Sullivan, wh don’t see.
Come on now, Finn. lLet’s make this easy. McGovern nods. MICHAEL’S POV: As Sullivan speaks, he steps right in fron the door. From now on, Sullivan’s feet partially obscure Michael’s view.
(slightly more threatening) We can’t hear you!
All right. Connor smiles

Good. Thank you. And I am sorry. I’m sorry for you loss. I’m sorry for this misunderstanding...and I’m sorry your brother was such a fuckin’ liar. Connor makes for the door. Two of McGovern’s men step out from the shadows. They are carrying RIFLES.
MICHAEL’S POV: Sullivan’s shoes two feet in front of his eyes.
McGovern ‘wrestling’ with himself - he wants to speak out
My brother was not a liar. Connor stops. Slight smile. Turns... nothing the two men, who close in around McGovern. Michael sees the shadows, but doesn’t see the men yet.
Excuse me?
To protect my family, and keep my job, I‘ll stay quiet. But don’t think I don’t know something’s going on. And don’t think I won’t find out what it is. Connor walks back toward McGovern.
Whoa... MICHAEL’S POV: Through his father’s legs he sees the men begin to raise their guns.

(to his men and Sullivan) Easy. We're just talking. (to Connor) You tell your father, my brother never stole from him. I’ve checked the books, he never sold no booze to no- one. Every single barrel is accounted for. (beat) Anyway if he’d’a sold it, where’s the money?
Fuck should I know? D’you check his mattress? (CONTINUED )
Maybe you should check yours.
Look, there’s something immoral here, don’t you think so Mike? My beloved father throws your undeserving little brother the wake of his life and this is your thank you? What a hideous world this is.

(rising to the bait) You think you’re so smart?! You think we don’t know? I mean, you’ve been spending so much time in Chicago... Connor whips out his PISTOL and puts two bullets into McGovern. As the COHORTS raise their rifles, SULLIVAN opens FIRE. The killing of all three men lasts five seconds: sudden, brutal, swift. The huge volume of the GUNFIRE echoes in the room. MICHAEL'S POV: through Sullivan's legs. Brass casings fal in front of his eyes. Horrified. The bloodied face of one of the men hits the floor direct in front of Michael's face. Eyes open. Michael frozen in terror.
Connor, exhilarate and frightened. He stands, breathing heavily.
(angry) What was that?
We’re outta here. Connor moves to the door. Sullivan is left standing.
Jesus Christ, Conor! What the hell are you thinking. (CONTINUED )
Connor keeps walking. Connor sees a HAND under the small door.
(pointing) There. Then Sullivan sees it. He runs to the door.

Sullivan barges out into the alley, brandishing his Tommy Gun, and chasing the fleeing figure. His exit is blocked by and iron fence, Michael cowers. Sullivan lowers his gun as he catches up to him. Then he sees who it is...
Oh, Jesus. Michael recoils. Sullivan stares in disbelief. Finally approaches, gun hanging at his side.
Michael Michael cowers. Can’t answer.
Are you hurt? A long beat. Michael crouches there in shock, trapped at end of the alley. He shakes his head no.
You saw everything? (off his nod) Jesus. He glances back to Connor, mind reeling, suddenly calcula a new host of dangers. Michael shivers in the rain.
You are not to speak of this to anyone. You understand? Not anyone! Connor approaches. Michael stares at the two men, nightma figures standing there, looking at him. (CONTINUED )
Who's this? (starring at Michael) Is this one of yours?
He must’ve been hiding in the car.
(calm sobriety) Can he keep a secret?
He’s my son. The two men gauge each other, tense. Connor re-groups, looks at Michael one last time, then tu to Sullivan.

Good enough for me. You take him home. I think I’1l walk. (beat. Puts his collar up) Perfect night for a stroll Connor steps from the doorway into the pouring rain. Sullivan watches him walk down the alley. Without turning back, Connor waves good night.
The car pulls into the garage. INT. SULLIVAN’S CAR - SULLIVAN GARAGE - NIGHT SULLIVAN kills the engine. They stare out at their home. Neither ready to go in.
Does Mama know?
You mother knows I love Mr. Rooney. When we had nothing, he gave us a home. A life. And we owe him. Do you understand? Michael looks to Sullivan. Pause. (CONTINUED )
Do you understand?
(nodding) Yes.
Come on inside. INT. BOYS’ BEDROOM - NIGHT Michael lies awake. He stares at the ceiling. The reflection of the rain. His hands are balled into fists.
CLOSE: Sullivan wipes down the gun. CLOSE: Cleans his hand. Sullivan packs up his machine gun into the black case. Pu the case in the cupboard and locks it. Stands, deep in thought.
Michael, Peter and Annie at Breakfast. Michael can’t eat. Sullivan enter. Sits. Looks at Michael who won’t look bac After a pause:
Boys, clear you plates, please.
I'll do it later.
It’s time for school now, just-
It’s only a plate. Annie, puzzled, looks to Sullivan for support... Sullivan just looks at the table, unable to respond. Annie is amazed. CAR HORN sounds outside.  25.
A large, BLACK CAR [Pierce Arrow] pulls up to the house. Peter rushes out. JIMMY is driving. He gets pit of the ca and opens the back door. ROONEY steps out. HUGS Peter.
Peter!
Sullivan watches, concerned as Michael comes out of the house. Annie comes to the window, next to him.
What’s he doing here? Sullivan looks to Annie.
Michael was hiding in the car when I wen out last night.
Oh Jesus, Mike-
(cutting her off) I’ve spoken to him. It won’t happen again.
Michael walks his bicycle toward the road. Rooney approac him.
Just the feller! (surreptitious) Our secret, right? Michael looks at him nervous. Rooney frowns.
I’m talking about the dice. Rooney hands him a large silver coin. Michael takes it, reluctantly.
A man of honor always pays his debts... (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
ROONEY (CONT’D) (he leans in, close) ..-and keeps his word.

I’m gonna be late for school. Michael pedals away. Rooney WATCHES him. Sullivan comes out of the house, putting on his coat. Rooney looks at the window. Annie watches him. He waves, friendly. CLOSE: Annie, worried.
Establishing shot.
Sullivan and Rooney sit inside a booth having coffee. Thi is Rooney’s local restaurant.
How is Michael? Is he OK?
(grateful) I’ve spoken to him. He understands.
That’s tough, seeing that for the first time. Sullivan remembers and nods. Rooney smiles, warmly;

Well--you turned out. (sensing his distress) You can’t protect him forever. If it wasn’t this, it'd be something else. (Off Sullivan's look.) Natural law. Sons are put on this earth to trouble their fathers. Sullivan loves this man.  27.

A cheering crowd of boys encouraging a FIGHT. As we move closer we see that it’s MICHAEL fighting with another (bigger) boy. Michael punches and kicks wildly - complete out of control. INT. ROONEY’S MANSION - GRAND PARLOR - EARLY EVENING ROONEY sits at the head of the long table. CONNOR on his right. SULLIVAN, behind, in shadow. Rooney’s bodyguards SEAN and JIMMY stand at the door. Eight other MEN at the table: representatives of various of the business: Distilleries. Casinos. Brothels. Food, coffee, drinks on the table. It’s towards the end of a meeting. There is ONE EMPTY CHAIR at the table: the one FINN McGOV used to sit in. JACK KELLY, a man in his 50’s, smart suit, the family’s accountant and lawyer is in mid-speech:

John also made it clear that Finn McGovern’s operation will be divided up locally among two territories that John will select personally. I'd like to take this moment to thank our friend Mister Rance, for interrupting a busy travel schedule to pay us a visit. RANCE is introduced, sitting at the table. He drinks lemo tea. He nods.
Thank you, Jack.
Mister Rance met with John and me earlier to make another bid for our involvement in the unions.
And I told Mister Rance what I told him before. What men do after work is what made us all rich. No need to screw ‘em at work as well. (CONTINUED )
Is there any other business?
Yes Rooney glances at an empty chair. A pause.
Connor, is there something you would like to say about last night? He looks at his son. CONNOR clearly wasn’t planning on talking. He’s unprepared and misreads the atmosphere...
(from his chair) I'd like to apologize for what happened. Especially toy you, Pa - two wakes in a month, what can I say? Pause. Some laughter in the room. Rooney is furious.
We lost a good man last night. You think it’s funny? Try again... Connor tries to maintain his cool.
I'd like to apologize for-- Bang! Rooney slams his hand on the table.
(not looking at him) You would like to apologize? TRY
Connor pushes away his chair and stands, like a disobedie child. The room doesn’t know where to look.
Gentlemen. My apologies. ON CONNOR: humiliated. An uncomfortable pause. Kelly, a decent man, lets Connor off the hook by moving on:
Is everyone clear about bit-borrowers? There’s been far too many debts outstanding. (CONTINUED )
Mike?
Just give me their names. Tell me who to visit.

Thank you gentlemen. (to Sullivan) Come upstairs. They all get up. Rooney puts his arm around Sullivan as they exit. Warm an familiar. CONNOR observes this. The room empties. He sits at the head of the huge table , alone. Deep in thought.

Michael has been kept behind after school. His TEACHER is marking books. Michael writes lines on the blackboard: I WILL NOT FIGHT WITH OTHER BOYS. EXT. ROONEY’S MANSION - DRIVEWAY - NIGHT (LATER) It’s later. Sullivan walks to his car.
Mike! Sullivan turns. Connor approaches him. He takes out a SEALED ENVELOPE.
Dad forgot to give you this. Reminder for Tony Calvino. Sullivan takes the letter, puts it in his coat pocket.
He’s light again.
You coming? (CONTINUED )
Nah. (slight smile) I’m under house arrest for a while. (beat) Look, I’m sorry about last night. I am. I was... you know. Beat.
Alright. SULLIVAN gets in the car. Connor waves him off.

Sullivan gets out of his car and makes for the BACK ENTRA of CALVINO’s speakeasy. He gets to the stairway, leading to a BASEMENT DOOR. A sign: SUBWAY POOL AND BILLIARDS. A bouncer (FRANK) stan at the bottom of the stairs. He turns.
Help you sir, or just lookin’?
Here to see Tony Calvino.
Yeah, and who are you?
Mike Sullivan Frank pales.
Oh. Yes sir.
You gonna frisk me?
